one teacher schools with more than 4 standards — maximum of 28 pupils.
Statistics are not immediately available on the number of posts allocated under the maximum class size guidelines but will be communicated to the Deputy as soon as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Clare School Capitation Grant.

Qst.Quest: when the payment of a maximum capitation grant will be made to Bansha national school, Kilkee, County Clare; and when responsibility for maintenance will be transferred to the local management.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Bansha national school is one of a number of schools which has been referred to in the past as Office of Public Works schools.

Arrangements for the transferral of responsibility for the maintenance of these schools to local management and the payment of full capitation grants to them are currently being considered in my Department.
Meantime, maintenance will be conducted by the Office of Public Works. The schools will continue to be paid capitation grant at the appropriate rate.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Teacher Retention.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if she will have arrangements made for the retention of the assistant teacher at Crossboyne Primary School, Claremorris, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The staffing of a national school is determined by the enrolment in the school on 30 September of the previous year.

MainHeading.P: In the case of Crossboyne Primary School there were 24 pupils enrolled on 30 September 1992 which warrants a staffing of principal only for the 1993-94 school year.
The post of first assistant is to be discontinued with effect from 31 August 1993, as the enrolment on 30 September, 1992 did not warrant its retention.

Qst.Quest: her views on the fact that equality of access to second level education is not available to children (details supplied) in the Cabra area of Dublin 7; and if her Department will assist in obtaining places in the local girls' second level school for the four children referred to.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am aware that difficulties have arisen for a number of pupils in the Cabra area of Dublin 7 in gaining admission to the second-level school of their choice.

A primary responsibility of my Department is to ensure that, overall, sufficient places exist at second-level to cater for demand in a given area. Intake policy is essentially a matter for each second-level school management subject to the application of acceptable criteria.

However, the Deputy may be assured that it is a matter of great concern to me and my Department that second-level schools in any given locality should fulfil their responsibilities in the delivery of education for all students regardless of their socio-economic or intellectual ability. My Department is in discussions with post-primary managerial authorities with a view to ensuring that all schools adopt this approach in their enrolment of pupils.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the number of separate public relations consultants who are currently employed in her Department; and her views on whether this represents a judicious use of taxpayers' funds.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: There are no public relations consultants employed by my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Downs Syndrome School Children.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the number of Downes Syndrome children currently attending primary schools; and the number of these children who have the services of specialist or visiting teachers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Information is not readily available on the number of children with Downs Syndrome currently attending primary schools.

The majority of these children are included among those assessed as moderately and mildly mentally handicapped who attend special schools and classes. These pupils benefit from the preferential pupil teacher ratios which apply to these types of schools and classes.
At present 44 Downs Syndrome children enrolled in ordinary primary schools receive the support of the visiting teacher service. Others receive the service of remedial and resource teachers.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Kildare School Sports Facilities.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the letter sent by her Department to Scoil Mhuire Community School, Clane, County Kildare, in 1986 outlining details of the sports facilities to be provided; and if funds will be made available to allow this development to proceed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The provision of a physical education hall and ancillary facilities at this school was proposed in 1986. However, due to financial constraints the planning of this proposal did not proceed.

MainHeading.P: Due to demands on the capital resources available priority has been given for some time to the provision of essential teaching places. As a result, it is not possible to make funding available at this stage for the provision of physical education facilities at the school in question.

The provision of indoor sports accommodation in existing schools, in the form of a general purpose area at primary level and a hall at secondary level will resume as soon as pressure on available resources for urgent classroom accommodation has eased. In the meantime, additional emphasis is being placed on the adjacent siting and common use of school and community recreational facilities. Schools should make maximum use of other sports facilities in their area.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of complaints (details supplied) from the parents of pupils attending St. Maelruan's Junior School, Tallaght, Dublin 24, she will give the steps, if any, she will take to eliminate these difficulties; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The complaints submitted by the parents referred to were investigated by the board of management of the school recently. The recommendations made by the board of management are being considered by my Department at present.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Saggart (Dublin) School.

Qst.Quest: if the report by officers of her Department into the loss of a teacher at St. Mary's national school in Saggart, County Dublin, has been completed; and if so, if she will make a copy of this report available to the parents and the school authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Investigations into the above matter have been completed.

MainHeading.P: The report was in the format of an internal departmental report for information of senior management in reviewing the matter. It is not normal procedure to make copies of such reports available to parents or to school authorities.

Qst.Quest: if she has had arrangements made for a second study to be carried out on the need for a second level school in Castleknock, Dublin 15; if so, if she will give details of the terms of reference of such a study; the person responsible for carrying out the study; the persons from whom that person will be seeking submissions; if she has satisfied herself that the period for the carrying out of this study is satisfactory in view of the fact that schools will be closed; and if she will give a commitment that this report will be published.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I have decided to have a further study carried out on the second-level needs of Castleknock, Dublin 15. The terms of reference and other details regarding the proposed study referred to by the Deputy are being finalised in my Department.
It is my intenion that, when the report has been completed and assessed in my Department, it will be made available to the local interest groups.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Junior Certificate Geography Paper.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the number of complaints received by her Department in respect of the Junior Certificate Geography Higher Course Paper.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The number of complaints received to date totals 40.
All complaints have been noted and discussed at the marking conference and will be taken into consideration, as appropriate, in the marking of the paper.

Qst.Quest: if she has clarified whether secondary school education will continue at a school (details supplied) in County Limerick from September 1995, as parents, teachers and pupils need to know so that first year pupils can be accepted in September 1993, and now that primary schools in the catchment areas are closed for the summer holidays; and if she will make a statement as to the position in order to eliminate the present uncertainty which prevails.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The Deputy will be aware of the decision taken by the trustees of the school in question to withdraw from management of the school in 1995 and to cease to enrol new pupils from September 1993. As the school is a voluntary secondary school, these decisions are matters solely for the school authorities.
A proposal has been put to my Department that the school should continue to operate as a post-primary school, after 1995, under the management of County Limerick Vocational Education Committee.
My Department has been examining this proposal in the light of the considerable, estimated costs involved in implementation.
I am aware of the concern of the parents, teachers and pupils on the matter and I anticipate communicating an early decision to the various interests involved.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, that has been made to date with regard to the provision of a permanent structure for students attending the Dungarvan Vocational School, Dungarvan, County Waterford; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: As I informed the Deputy in reply to Question No. 107 tabled by him on 11 March 1993, the architectural planning of a new vocational school building was suspended in 1987 in the light of the declining demographic trend and its implication for future post-primary enrolments in Dungarvan.

County Waterford Vocational Education Committee has recently submitted proposals for the provision of a major extension to the existing vocational school building in Dungarvan. In April I met a deputation from the vocational education committee to discuss the proposal. In June a senior official of my Department visited the vocational school and met vocational education committee representatives.
The vocational education committee proposals, which would involve an estimated expenditure of over £1 million are now being further considered within my Department.
